bioghist.p: Margaret Cheek Blood (1918-1999) was born in Cincinnati, Ohio. While attending Yale Divinity School, she became involved in the Society of Friends. She married Robert O. Blood (1921-1988), also a Quaker, in Lexington, Kentucky. During World War II, they worked with Japanese-Americans interned in Arkansas. In 1952 they moved to Ann Arbor, Michigan. Margaret led the First Day School there for many years. She was also involved with the United Nations Associations, Women's Strike for Peace, and the Interfaith Council for Peace. Robert O. Blood was a social science researcher at the University of Michigan. He was the author of several textbooks on marriage and the family. Blood wrote as a social scientist and neither Quakerism nor overt moralism was present in his texts. Together, the Bloods worked at Pendle Hill as co-leaders of workshops on personal growth and creative movement. In 1973 they opened a retreat and counseling center in their home.

scopecontent.p: This is a collection of the papers of Margaret and Robert Blood. Materials of Margaret Blood include greeting cards and incoming and outgoing correspondence; journals and notebooks; notes on her childhood; a small batch of estate and medical records; and documents on the memorial service for Robert Blood. Materials of Robert Blood include transcribed descriptions of dreams and school papers from his time at Yale. The collection also includes notes by the Bloods and participating couples on the couples workshops run by the Bloods; resource materials for the workshops, such as music and games; a small number of family photos; and newspaper clippings on and correspondence of their son Peter Blood.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.
